content.user_title: Process PDF Files with Python Libraries
content.value_statement: Working with PDF files often requires specialized knowledge of multiple Python libraries and their APIs. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for extracting text and tables, filling forms, merging documents, and handling PDF processing tasks using pdfplumber and pypdf libraries.
actual_capabilities: Extract text and tables from PDF documents using pdfplumber
Fill PDF forms programmatically with pypdf library
Merge multiple PDF files into a single document
Split PDFs and extract specific page ranges
Flatten PDF forms to make them non-editable
Validate form data before filling PDF fields
limitations: Does not support OCR for scanned PDFs without additional setup of tesseract
Cannot edit or modify existing PDF content, only extract or fill forms
Requires Python environment with pdfplumber and pypdf libraries installed
Table extraction accuracy depends on PDF structure and formatting

use_cases.title: Automate Form Processing
use_cases.description: Legal professionals can automatically fill standardized legal forms with client data from databases or spreadsheets, reducing manual data entry errors and saving hours of repetitive work.

use_cases.title: Extract Financial Data
use_cases.description: Data analysts can extract tables and text from financial reports and invoices to import into analysis tools, enabling automated processing of hundreds of documents for reporting and compliance.

use_cases.title: Batch Document Processing
use_cases.description: Developers can merge multiple PDF reports into consolidated documents, split large PDFs into sections, or extract specific pages for distribution to different stakeholders.

output_examples.input: Extract text from the first page of document.pdf
output_examples.output: The skill provides Python code using pdfplumber that opens the PDF, extracts text from the first page, and displays the extracted content. The code includes error handling for empty pages or unreadable text.

output_examples.input: Fill the contact form with my information and flatten it
output_examples.output: The skill generates Python code that reads the PDF form, updates specified fields with provided values, flattens the form to prevent further editing, and saves the result to a new file. The code includes field validation to ensure required data is present.

output_examples.input: Merge three PDF files into one document
output_examples.output: The skill creates code using pypdf PdfMerger class that combines the specified PDF files in order, writes the merged output to a new file, and properly closes all file handles to avoid resource leaks.

best_practices: Always validate input data before filling PDF forms to ensure required fields are populated and data formats are correct
Work on copies of original PDF files to preserve source documents and enable recovery from processing errors
Close PDF objects after use and handle exceptions to prevent resource leaks when processing large batches of files
anti_patterns: Attempting to extract text from scanned PDFs without OCR setup will result in empty output or errors
Processing entire large PDFs when only specific pages are needed wastes memory and processing time
Failing to flatten forms after filling allows recipients to modify sensitive data that should be locked

faq.question: What Python libraries does this skill use for PDF processing?
faq.answer: The skill primarily uses pdfplumber for text and table extraction, and pypdf for form filling, merging, and splitting. Additional libraries like pdf2image and pytesseract are mentioned for OCR tasks.

faq.question: Can this skill extract text from scanned PDF documents?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidance for using pytesseract for OCR on scanned PDFs, but this requires additional system-level installation of tesseract software beyond the Python libraries.

faq.question: How do I handle PDFs with no extractable text?
faq.answer: The skill includes error handling examples that check if extracted text is empty or None, which typically indicates a scanned PDF that requires OCR processing rather than direct text extraction.

faq.question: Can I edit existing text content in a PDF?
faq.answer: No, the skill focuses on extraction, form filling, and document manipulation. PDFs are not designed for content editing, and the libraries used do not support modifying existing text within the document.

faq.question: What is form flattening and when should I use it?
faq.answer: Form flattening converts editable form fields into static content, making the PDF non-editable. Use this when distributing filled forms to prevent recipients from changing data that should be locked.

faq.question: How accurate is table extraction from PDFs?
faq.answer: Table extraction accuracy depends on how well-structured the PDF is. Tables with clear borders and consistent formatting extract well, while complex or poorly formatted tables may require manual adjustment of extraction settings.
